SENT.plain: We report on two women who underwent myocardial revascularization associated with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) with different pathogenic patterns
The first woman presented with acute myocardial infarction, and preoperative angiograms demonstrated rapidly progressing coronary lesions, presumptive unstable plaque, and dissection
Operative findings, however, showed fresh thrombi in the coronary arteries, and she was diagnosed postoperatively as having APS
Her one-year angiogram demonstrated improved coronary lesions and a competitive flow pattern in the grafts
The second woman presented with unstable angina and had been treated for systemic lupus erythematosus and secondary APS for more than 14 years
She underwent myocardial revascularization due to accelerated coronary atherosclerosis
Her one-year angiogram demonstrated patent grafts
